slides.content: Key anions to memorize: NO3- (nitrate), NO2- (nitrite), SO4(2-) (sulfate), SO3(2-) (sulfite), PO4(3-) (phosphate), CO3(2-) (carbonate)
Common cations: NH4+ (ammonium) — behaves like a positive polyatomic ion you see often
Charge reminders: Many O-rich ions carry negative charges (oxyanions). Learn charges alongside the formula.
Mnemonic idea: 'Naughty Nitrates, Sulfur Sometimes' — pair NO3/NO2 and SO4/SO3 to recall -ate vs -ite

slides.content: -ate vs -ite: -ate has one more O than -ite (example: sulfate SO4(2-) vs sulfite SO3(2-))
per- prefix: one more O than -ate (ex: perchlorate ClO4-)
hypo- prefix: one less O than -ite (ex: hypochlorite ClO-)
Practice with chlorine family: ClO-, ClO2-, ClO3-, ClO4- = hypo-, -ite, -ate, per- order

slides.content: Bronsted-Lowry: Acid = proton (H+) donor. Base = proton acceptor.
Conjugate pairs: HA <-> H+ + A-. When HA loses H+, it becomes A- (the conjugate base).
Lewis perspective: acid accepts an electron pair; base donates an electron pair.

slides.content: Common strong acids: HCl, HBr, HI, HNO3, HClO4, (and H2SO4 for the first H+)
Weak acids: partially dissociate (example: CH3COOH, H2CO3). Equilibrium arrows!
In titrations strong acid vs weak base curves differ — endpoint pH differs.

slides.content: Strong acid: [H+] equals initial acid concentration (ignoring autoionization of water).
pH formula: pH = -log10([H+]). Example: 0.001 M HCl → pH = 3
For weak acids use ICE tables and Ka — not covered in this quick slide.

slides.content: Complete combustion (enough O2): hydrocarbon + O2 -> CO2 + H2O
Incomplete combustion (limited O2): hydrocarbon -> CO, C (soot), sometimes CO2 and H2O
Safety note: CO produced in incomplete combustion is toxic — ventilation matters.

slides.content: Equation: C3H8 + O2 -> CO2 + H2O
Step 1: Balance C: C3H8 -> 3 CO2
Step 2: Balance H: C3H8 -> 4 H2O (8 H total)
Step 3: Count O: right side has 3*2 + 4*1 = 10 O atoms → need 5 O2 on left. Final: C3H8 + 5O2 -> 3CO2 + 4H2O
